caption: Table 1: ReFocus yields consistent performance gains across all tasks and outperforms all baselines. Notice that the GPT baselines here are also in a conversational format but without editing abilities. For fair comparison, we modify the original Visprog [10] framework by replacing the LM and VQA components with the latest GPT-4o model.
description: This table presents a comprehensive comparison of various models' performance on several structured image understanding tasks, including those involving tables and charts.  The models are assessed based on their accuracy in answering visual questions related to these image types. The table showcases ReFocus's consistent improvement over multiple baseline models, highlighting its effectiveness in enhancing the visual reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs).  The results demonstrate significant performance gains across various datasets, especially when compared to models without visual editing capabilities. The baseline model Visprog [10] was modified to use the latest GPT-4o model for a fairer comparison to ensure consistent LLM power.

caption:
Table 2: Open-source models’ performance upon the original visual input versus GPT-4o + ReFocus edited images as visual input (referred by + oracle ReFocus).
Notice that + oracle ReFocus uses the visual artifact generated in the last action of GPT-4o + ReFocus as inputs.
description: This table compares the performance of several open-source multimodal large language models (LLMs) on structured image understanding tasks.  It shows the accuracy of these models when processing images with and without visual edits produced by the ReFocus framework.  The 'original visual input' column presents the results using the original images, while the '+ Oracle ReFocus' column displays the results after the images have been edited using visual edits generated by GPT-4 + ReFocus.  The '+Oracle ReFocus' results utilize the final edited image produced by the GPT-4 + ReFocus pipeline. This highlights the impact of ReFocus-generated visual edits on the performance of different LLMs.

caption: Table 3: ReFocus empowers GPT-4o to achieve the performance as if given gold text input. The text input are mainly csv tables, as detailed in Section 3.1. Notice that Table 1 reports the conversational performance without visual editing, whereas the performance discussed here is based on direct question answering, leading to minor differences.
description: This table compares the performance of GPT-4o with and without ReFocus on various structured image understanding tasks.  It highlights that ReFocus enables GPT-4o to achieve similar accuracy to models given gold standard text inputs (CSV tables), even though ReFocus only utilizes visual editing and doesn't add any extra information. The results show improved performance compared to the conversational format results presented in Table 1, which didn't utilize image editing. This difference stems from the use of direct question answering in this table, versus the conversational approach in Table 1.  Note that the input data consisted primarily of CSV tables, as discussed in Section 3.1.

content:
Dataset Original Mask out Draw Box Highlight
VWTQ 66.4 77.2 77.6 74.8
VWTQ_syn 70.4 82.4 78.8 80.8
caption: Table 4: Analysis on how different editing tool can affect model performance. We control the tool type provided by ReFocus and experiment on the VWTQ and VWTQ_syn datasets.
description: This table presents the results of an experiment designed to assess the impact of different visual editing tools on the performance of a multimodal large language model (LLM) in a visual question answering (VQA) task.  The experiment focused on two datasets: VWTQ and VWTQ_syn, both involving tabular data.  The model's performance was evaluated under conditions where different visual editing tools provided by ReFocus were selectively applied. Each tool (mask out, draw box, highlight) modified the input image differently. The table shows how the model's accuracy varies depending on the type of visual edit used, offering insights into the relative effectiveness of each tool in facilitating visual reasoning for enhanced VQA.

Visual CoT Prompting
Phi-3.5-vision [12] 69.4 66.8 68.2
SFT w/ QA Data 60.6 66.8 63.4
SFT w/ ReFocus CoT 67.1 70.7 68.8
SFT w/ ReFocus VCoT 71.0 72.2 71.4
caption:
Table 5: SFT accuracy results. The difference between ReFocus VCoT data and CoT data is that VCoT contains refocus area bounding box coordinates whereas CoT does not.
All trainings select the best performing hyper-parameters on the same set of training data.
description: This table presents the results of supervised fine-tuning (SFT) experiments using different types of training data: standard question-answer (QA) pairs, chain-of-thought (CoT) data, and ReFocus visual CoT data.  The ReFocus visual CoT data includes not only the chain of thought and the final answer, but also the bounding box coordinates of the image regions that the model focused on during the reasoning process. The table shows the accuracy achieved on horizontal and vertical bar chart question answering tasks, highlighting the significant performance gains obtained by using ReFocus visual CoT data compared to QA pairs and standard CoT data.  All models were trained with the same set of hyperparameters to ensure a fair comparison.

It provides the total number of training examples, categorized into those with visual editing and those without. This breakdown helps in understanding the composition of the training data and its impact on model performance.

description: This table presents the hyperparameter settings used to achieve the best performance in the fine-tuned models during the supervised fine-tuning experiments.  It shows the data type (bf16), batch size (64), learning rate (ranging from 5e-7 to 1e-6), number of epochs (2), and whether edited images were included in the input (Yes/No).  These settings were optimized for different configurations of the REFOCUS dataset.
